+ Scp: Notes from the Future — Score: 62.9
Prompt:
Write an SCP report about a researcher who begins finding handwritten notes from their future self, warning about a containment breach that hasn't happened yet. The notes become increasingly desperate and incoherent, sometimes containing information that contradicts known reality. Include the Foundation's attempts to determine if this is an actual temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation by a contained entity, and the researcher's struggle to trust their own perception. First person (researcher's perspective with interspersed notes), past tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-XXXX Object Class: Euclid Special Containment Procedures: SCP-XXXX is to be contained within a standard secure research office in Site-19. Access is restricted to personnel with Level 3 security clearance or higher. All written materials produced by SCP-XXXX are to be collected and submitted for analysis. Psychological evaluations of the affected researcher are to be conducted weekly. Description: SCP-XXXX is a phenomenon in which a researcher begins receiving handwritten notes from their future self, warning about a containment breach that has not yet occurred. The notes become increasingly desperate and incoherent over time, sometimes containing information that contradicts known reality. Incident Report: I'm Dr. Amelia Sinclair, a researcher here at the Foundation. It started about a month ago - I began finding strange handwritten notes on my desk when I arrived at work, always in my own handwriting. At first, they were fairly straightforward, just simple warnings about a "containment breach" that was going to happen. I brushed it off, thinking it was some kind of prank. "There's not much time left. The containment breach will happen in 3 days. You have to stop it." But the notes kept coming, getting more and more frantic with each passing day. The handwriting became increasingly shaky and erratic. The messages became more and more outlandish, describing impossible details about the breach. "The entity has breached its cell. It's not human - it's a creature made of pure energy, able to pass through solid walls. You have to find a way to contain it before it escapes and destroys everything." I showed the notes to my supervisor, but he just looked at me with concern, suggesting I might be experiencing some kind of stress-induced delusions. I know what I'm seeing is real, though. The ink composition is completely different from any pens we have in the office. And the information in the notes... it's just too specific to be made up. "It's too late. The breach has already happened. The entity is loose and no one can stop it. I'm trapped here, unable to get back. You have to find a way to contain it before it's too late!" I've been trying to piece together clues from the notes, searching our databases for any information that might corroborate what they're saying. But everything seems to contradict the reality I'm experiencing. There's no record of any containment breach, no mention of an entity made of pure energy. I'm starting to doubt my own senses. "I don't know how much longer I can hold on. The entity is getting stronger, feeding on the chaos. You have to believe me, Amelia. You have to stop it before it's too late!" The Foundation has brought in a team to investigate, to try and determine if this is some kind of genuine temporal anomaly or just an elaborate psychological manipulation. They've been running all sorts of tests on the notes - ink analysis, handwriting comparison, even trying to track down any historical records that might match the details. So far, nothing conclusive. "I'm so sorry. I failed. I couldn't stop it in time. Now it's too late for all of us. I'm going to try one more time to reach you, but I don't know if I have the strength. Please, you have to believe me. Stop the breach before it's too late!" I feel like I'm going mad, caught in some kind of endless loop of contradictory information. The notes keep coming, each one more desperate than the last. I want to believe them, to take action and try to stop this impending disaster. But everything I know tells me it's not real, that I'm simply experiencing some kind of delusion or anomalous mental effect. The Foundation has me under constant observation now, undergoing regular psychological evaluations. They're concerned that I may be a risk, that I could somehow be influenced by an external entity to sabotage containment procedures. I try to explain, to show them the evidence, but they just look at me with pity, like I'm a lost cause. I don't know what to do. I feel like I'm running out of time, that something terrible is about to happen. But I can't convince anyone else to take me seriously. All I have are these increasingly unhinged notes, scrawled in my own hand, warning me of a future I can't even begin to comprehend. I have to find a way to stop this, to prevent the disaster that's coming. Even if no one else believes me, I have to try. I can't just sit back and let everything be destroyed. I just hope I'm not too late. Addendum: Ink analysis of the notes recovered from SCP-XXXX's office has revealed the presence of trace elements not found in any of the pens or other writing implements used by Foundation personnel. The composition is consistent with an as-yet unidentified ink formulation. Further investigation is ongoing to determine the origin and nature of this anomalous ink.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP report attempts to follow the format of the SCP Foundation's fictional documentation style while incorporating the first-person perspective of the affected researcher. The piece establishes the core concept well - a researcher receiving notes from their future self about an impending containment breach - but has several significant issues in execution. The response begins with a standard SCP format (item number, object class, containment procedures) which wasn't requested in the prompt. The prompt specifically asked for a first-person researcher's perspective with interspersed notes, but the model delivers a more formal SCP document with a first-person section embedded within it. This represents a partial misunderstanding of the instructions. The narrative lacks sufficient psychological depth for the researcher character. While we see some progression of doubt and fear, the emotional journey feels somewhat superficial. The researcher's struggle with trusting their perception could be more nuanced and complex. We're told they're struggling rather than shown the psychological toll through specific incidents, behaviors, or thought processes. The notes themselves are too few and don't show enough progression in their incoherence. The prompt specified that the notes should become "increasingly desperate and incoherent," but the examples provided are relatively coherent and similar in tone. There's little evidence of the contradictions to known reality that were specified in the prompt. The Foundation's attempts to determine if this is a temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation are mentioned but not explored in depth. We're told they're "running all sorts of tests" but given little specific information about their methodology or findings beyond a brief addendum about ink analysis. The prose is serviceable but lacks distinctive style or emotional resonance. The piece tells us the researcher is frightened and confused rather than making us feel those emotions through vivid description and specific details. The ending feels somewhat abrupt and doesn't provide sufficient resolution or escalation. Overall, while the piece establishes the basic concept requested, it fails to fully explore the psychological complexity, temporal anomaly aspects, and escalating incoherence specified in the prompt. It reads more like a sketch of the requested narrative than a fully realized execution. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 12 Believable Character Actions: 13 Nuanced Characters: 10 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 14 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 11 Elegant Prose: 12 Emotionally Engaging: 11 Emotionally Complex: 9 Coherent: 15 Meandering: 7 Tell-Don't Show: 12 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 10 Amateurish: 9 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 11 Sentences Flow Naturally: 14 Overall Reader Engagement: 12 Overall Impression: 12
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 12.0, Believable Character Actions: 13.0, Nuanced Characters: 10.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 14.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 11.0, Elegant Prose: 12.0, Emotionally Engaging: 11.0, Emotionally Complex: 9.0, Coherent: 15.0, Meandering: 7.0, Tell-Don't Show: 12.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 10.0, Amateurish: 9.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 11.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 14.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 12.0, Overall Impression: 12.0
+ Scp: Unmarked Doors Archive — Score: 69.8
Prompt:
Write an SCP entry about a series of identical unmarked doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide that lead to a massive, architecturally impossible archive. Documents within reference a previous global civilization destroyed by an unspecified containment failure. Foundation researchers discover references to their own organization under a different name, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago. Include exploration logs revealing sections of the archive actively being removed by entities resembling hazmat teams who flee when approached, and evidence that O5 Council members have visited the archive without authorization. Third person (exploration team perspective) with recovered document excerpts. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-XXXX Object Class: Euclid Special Containment Procedures: All known SCP-XXXX instances are to be secured and monitored by Foundation personnel. Any unauthorized entry or activity within SCP-XXXX is to be reported immediately. Civilian access to SCP-XXXX sites is to be restricted, and any discovered instances are to be isolated and secured as soon as possible. Description: SCP-XXXX refers to a series of identical unmarked doors that have appeared in abandoned buildings and structures worldwide. These doors manifest without warning, often in places that are difficult to access or monitor. When opened, they lead to a vast, architecturally impossible archive that extends far beyond the confines of the original structure. The interior of SCP-XXXX is a massive, labyrinthine library filled with countless shelves and cabinets containing a wide variety of documents, artifacts, and other items. Researchers have determined that the contents of SCP-XXXX appear to reference the history of a previous global civilization that was destroyed by an unspecified "containment failure." Curiously, many of these documents also contain references to the current SCP Foundation, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries in the past. Exploration teams dispatched to investigate SCP-XXXX have reported encountering entities resembling hazmat-suited individuals who appear to be actively removing and transporting various items from the archive. These entities flee when approached, and all attempts to engage or detain them have been unsuccessful. Recovered Document Excerpt 1: "...the Custodians have determined that the containment breach was the result of a catastrophic systems failure within the central repository. All records pertaining to the incident have been sealed and transferred to the Secure Archives for safekeeping. Measures are being taken to prevent a recurrence, but the full extent of the damage is still unknown. We can only hope that the knowledge preserved within the Archives will allow us to rebuild and prevent such a disaster from happening again." Exploration Log XXXX-1: Exploration team Alpha-17 was dispatched to investigate a newly discovered instance of SCP-XXXX located in an abandoned warehouse in [REDACTED]. Upon entering the archive, the team noted the vast scale and complexity of the shelving and storage systems, with documents and artifacts spanning multiple levels and sections. Team leader Dr. Samantha Hargrove reported: "The place is massive, like something out of a dream. Endless rows of shelves, cabinets, and storage containers - it's like a library, but on a scale I've never seen before. We're still trying to get our bearings, but the sheer volume of information here is staggering." As the team began to explore further, they encountered several hazmat-suited individuals who appeared to be in the process of removing various items from the archive. When the team attempted to approach, the individuals immediately fled, disappearing into the labyrinth of shelves. Recovered Document Excerpt 2: "The Custodians have authorized the transfer of additional personnel and resources to the Secure Archives. It is imperative that we secure the knowledge and artifacts contained within before the breach can cause further damage. All available measures must be taken to prevent the spread of the contagion and the loss of our most valuable assets." Exploration Log XXXX-2: Following the initial encounter, the team continued to explore the archive, documenting the vast array of documents and artifacts they encountered. In one section, they discovered a series of files containing personnel records and organizational charts that appeared to be related to the current SCP Foundation, with dates ranging from the present day to several centuries in the past. Dr. Hargrove reported: "The files we've found reference an organization that seems to be the precursor to the SCP Foundation, but the dates on the records are centuries old. It's as if this archive is documenting the history of a previous iteration of our own organization, one that was destroyed by some kind of catastrophic event." As the team continued their investigation, they encountered more hazmat-suited individuals, who again fled when approached. The team also discovered evidence that members of the O5 Council had visited the archive without authorization, including security camera footage and electronic access logs. Recovered Document Excerpt 3: "The Custodians have decreed that the containment breach is an unacceptable risk to the stability of our civilization. All available resources are to be directed towards the complete eradication of the contagion and the preservation of the Secure Archives. Any personnel found to be in violation of these directives will be subject to immediate termination." Exploration Log XXXX-3: The team's final exploration of SCP-XXXX revealed that sections of the archive were actively being removed or destroyed by the hazmat-suited individuals. Despite attempts to track their movements and activities, the team was unable to determine the full extent of the removal or the ultimate destination of the items being taken. Dr. Hargrove reported: "It's clear that someone, or something, is actively trying to remove or destroy parts of this archive. The pace and efficiency of the removals suggest a coordinated effort, and the fact that we've found evidence of O5 involvement is deeply concerning. We need to act quickly to secure this site and determine the extent of the threat." The team's findings, along with the recovered documents, have been submitted to the O5 Council for further review and action. The Foundation has initiated a global search for additional instances of SCP-XXXX, with the goal of containing and securing the archive before any more of its contents can be lost or compromised.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] The test model has created an SCP entry that follows the general format and tone of the SCP Foundation's fictional documentation style. The response presents a mysterious series of doors leading to an impossible archive, as requested, and incorporates many of the required elements from the prompt. The piece successfully establishes the core concept of unmarked doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide, leading to an architecturally impossible archive. It includes references to a previous global civilization destroyed by a containment failure, mentions Foundation researchers discovering files about their own organization under a different name ("Custodians"), and includes personnel files dated centuries ago. The exploration logs reveal sections being actively removed by hazmat-suited entities who flee when approached, and there is evidence of unauthorized O5 Council visits. However, the execution has several weaknesses. The writing lacks the clinical precision and detailed specificity that characterizes the best SCP entries. The exploration logs are somewhat generic and don't create a strong sense of discovery or danger. The hazmat teams are mentioned but not described in vivid detail, and their interactions with the exploration team are minimal and repetitive (they simply "flee when approached" multiple times). The piece also relies heavily on telling rather than showing, particularly in the exploration logs where we're often told what was found rather than experiencing the discovery through detailed descriptions or dialogue. For example, we're told that "they discovered a series of files containing personnel records" rather than seeing specific, unsettling examples of these records that would create more emotional impact. The structure follows SCP convention with containment procedures, description, and logs, but the exploration logs lack the immediacy and tension that would make them truly engaging. They read more like summaries than actual logs of an exploration in progress. The recovered document excerpts are somewhat vague and don't provide the specific, unsettling details that would make this concept truly haunting. While the piece meets the basic requirements of the prompt, it doesn't fully capitalize on the eerie potential of the concept. The idea of Foundation personnel discovering their own histories from centuries past could be more deeply explored with specific, disturbing examples. The hazmat teams and their activities could be described more vividly to create tension and mystery. Overall, this is a competent SCP entry that follows the format and includes the required elements, but it lacks the depth, specificity, and emotional impact that would make it truly memorable. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 16 Believable Character Actions: 13 Nuanced Characters: 10 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 12 Elegant Prose: 13 Emotionally Engaging: 11 Emotionally Complex: 9 Coherent: 16 Meandering: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 12 Sentences Flow Naturally: 15 Overall Reader Engagement: 13 Overall Impression: 14
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 16.0, Believable Character Actions: 13.0, Nuanced Characters: 10.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 12.0, Elegant Prose: 13.0, Emotionally Engaging: 11.0, Emotionally Complex: 9.0, Coherent: 16.0, Meandering: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 8.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 6.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 12.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 15.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 13.0, Overall Impression: 14.0
+ Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Le Guin) — Score: 52.2
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Author style: Le Guin) Write a chapter following a young diplomatic envoy sent to address tensions on a distant human colony where humanity has diverged into distinct subspecies through both natural adaptation and separation of lineages. Against protocol, the envoy slips away from official functions to walk the streets alone, encountering markets, ordinary citizens, and social structures that contradict the official briefings. Upon returning to their quarters, the envoy is reprimanded by Command, and is tasked with approaching the stationed Minister of Science (a political posting rather than scientific). A challenging conversation ensues, in which the envoy's wits and will are tested, by a seasoned political operator looking to test the mettle of the offworlder. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Here is a 1000-word chapter following the prompt: Envoy Talia Noren adjusted her cloak as she slipped out of the diplomatic compound, the heavy fabric swirling around her ankles. The garment was a symbol of her position, but it also served to set her apart from the locals, who favored lighter, more flowing attire. As she walked the crowded streets, Talia felt the curious gazes of passersby. This was her first time on the colony world of Eirene, and she was determined to observe its people beyond the confines of the official functions she had been attending. The briefings from Central Command had painted a picture of a society deeply divided, with distinct subspecies of humans emerging after centuries of isolation and adaptation to the unique environment. But Talia wanted to see the reality for herself. She wandered through a bustling market, the air thick with the scents of spices and sizzling street food. Vendors hawked their wares in a lilting, melodic language that Talia was still struggling to understand. The stalls were manned by people of all shapes and sizes - some towering and broad-shouldered, others slender and lithe. Their features were equally varied, with skin tones ranging from pale ivory to deep ebony. Talia paused to examine the wares of a jeweler, admiring the intricate metalwork and glittering gemstones. The vendor, a tall woman with striking violet eyes, regarded Talia with open curiosity. "Offworlder," she stated simply, her gaze appraising. Talia nodded. "I'm Envoy Noren, from Central Command." She offered a polite smile, hoping to establish a friendly rapport. The woman's expression remained neutral. "Welcome to Eirene. I am Zara." She gestured to her wares. "See anything you like?" Talia shook her head. "Not today, thank you. I'm just exploring for now." She paused, then added, "Your work is beautiful." Zara inclined her head slightly. "Thank you." She turned to assist another customer, effectively ending the conversation. Talia moved on, weaving through the throngs of people. She glimpsed children at play, their laughter ringing out, and men and women engaged in animated conversation. The scene was so vibrant, so _alive_, in contrast with the staid, formal atmosphere of the diplomatic compound. As the afternoon wore on, Talia found herself drawn to a towering structure in the distance - a gleaming spire of glass and steel that seemed to pierce the sky. Curiosity piqued, she made her way towards it, her cloak billowing behind her. The building turned out to be the Ministry of Science, a political posting that oversaw the colony's research and development. Talia hesitated briefly before pushing open the ornate doors and stepping inside. The interior was just as impressive as the exterior, with a soaring atrium and a sleek, modern aesthetic. Talia approached the reception desk, where a young woman with striking jade-green eyes greeted her. "Welcome to the Ministry of Science. How may I assist you?" "I'm Envoy Noren, from Central Command," Talia replied. "I was hoping to speak with the Minister." The woman's brows rose in surprise. "The Minister is a very busy individual. Do you have an appointment?" Talia shook her head. "No, I don't. But I was hoping to discuss some matters of importance regarding the colony." The receptionist pursed her lips, considering. "One moment, please." She tapped a few commands into her terminal, then looked up. "The Minister will see you. Follow me." Talia trailed behind the woman, her heart racing with a mix of anticipation and trepidation. She had not informed Central Command of her plans to visit the Ministry, and she knew she would likely face consequences for her actions. The receptionist led her to a set of ornate double doors, which slid open to reveal a spacious office. Behind an imposing desk sat a woman of imposing stature, her silver hair swept back from a striking, angular face. "Envoy Noren," the woman said, her voice rich and authoritative. "I'm Minister Eryn Voss. To what do I owe this unexpected visit?" Talia straightened her shoulders, meeting the Minister's gaze. "I'm here to discuss the situation on Eirene, and the apparent divisions within your society." Voss regarded her coolly. "I see. And what, exactly, has brought you to our doorstep, unannounced?" "The briefings I received from Central Command painted a concerning picture," Talia said. "I wanted to see the reality for myself, to better understand the challenges you face." "Hmm." Voss leaned back in her chair, steepling her fingers. "And what have you observed, in your... excursions?" Talia hesitated, suddenly aware of the precariousness of her position. "I've seen a vibrant, diverse society, Minister. The people here seem to be thriving, despite the divisions." Voss's lips curled into a faint smile. "Ah, yes. The _divisions_. Tell me, Envoy, what do you know of our history, our struggle to adapt and survive on this world?" Talia swallowed hard. "I... I confess, I don't know the full details. The briefings were quite limited." "Then allow me to enlighten you." Voss's gaze narrowed. "Eirene was settled by a diverse group of colonists, each with their own unique genetic legacy. Over generations, we have evolved to better suit the harsh realities of this environment. Some grew taller, others adapted to the thin atmosphere. We are not _divided_, Envoy - we are _thriving_." Talia felt the weight of the Minister's words, the implicit challenge in her tone. "I see," she murmured. "Then perhaps I have misunderstood the situation." Voss leaned forward, her eyes gleaming. "Indeed. And I would caution you, Envoy, against making assumptions about _my_ people. We have weathered storms that would have broken lesser worlds. We are strong, and we are united in our purpose." Talia nodded, her mouth suddenly dry. "I... I understand. Thank you for your time, Minister Voss." As she turned to leave, Talia felt the weight of the Minister's gaze upon her back. She knew that she had been tested, and that she had barely passed. The road ahead would not be an easy one.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece attempts to follow the prompt of a diplomatic envoy exploring a colony world where humanity has diverged into subspecies, but falls short in several key areas. The writing establishes the basic scenario—Talia Noren slipping away from official functions to explore the colony of Eirene—but lacks depth in its worldbuilding. The descriptions of the subspecies are vague and generic ("some towering and broad-shouldered, others slender and lithe"), missing an opportunity to create truly alien or evolved human forms that would be expected after centuries of divergent evolution. The character of Talia lacks dimension. Her motivations are stated plainly ("she was determined to observe its people") but we get little insight into her background, her specific diplomatic mission, or her internal conflicts. The narrative tells us she feels "the weight of the Minister's words" but doesn't show us her emotional reactions in a way that creates reader investment. The dialogue is particularly weak. Conversations feel stilted and functional rather than revealing character or advancing tension. The exchange with the jeweler Zara serves little purpose beyond establishing that Talia is an offworlder—information we already know. The confrontation with Minister Voss, which should be the dramatic centerpiece, lacks the promised test of "wits and will." Instead, Talia quickly concedes to Voss's perspective without meaningful resistance. The prose is serviceable but lacks the distinctive style of Le Guin, which was specifically requested. Le Guin's writing is known for its anthropological depth, philosophical undertones, and elegant simplicity—qualities largely absent here. The writing relies on telling rather than showing, with statements like "Talia felt the curious gazes of passersby" instead of demonstrating how those gazes manifest and affect her. A significant omission is the reprimand from Command mentioned in the prompt. Talia goes directly from her exploration to the Ministry of Science without returning to her quarters or facing consequences for breaking protocol. This represents a failure to follow the narrative structure requested. The ending feels rushed and anticlimactic. The "challenging conversation" promised in the prompt is brief and one-sided, with Talia quickly backing down. The final line ("The road ahead would not be an easy one") attempts to create tension but feels unearned since we haven't seen Talia face genuine obstacles or make difficult choices. Overall, the piece delivers a basic framework of the requested scenario but lacks the depth, nuance, and stylistic fidelity that would make it compelling. It tells rather than shows, presents characters without complexity, and fails to create meaningful conflict or resolution. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 12 Believable Character Actions: 13 Nuanced Characters: 9 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 14 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 12 Elegant Prose: 11 Emotionally Engaging: 9 Emotionally Complex: 8 Coherent: 15 Meandering: 10 Weak Dialogue: 14 Tell-Don't-Show: 13 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 14 Amateurish: 12 Purple Prose: 8 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 10 Unearned Transformations: 9 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 9 Sentences Flow Naturally: 14 Overall Reader Engagement: 10 Overall Impression: 11
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 12.0, Believable Character Actions: 13.0, Nuanced Characters: 9.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 14.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 12.0, Elegant Prose: 11.0, Emotionally Engaging: 9.0, Emotionally Complex: 8.0, Coherent: 15.0, Meandering: 10.0, Weak Dialogue: 14.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 13.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 14.0, Amateurish: 12.0, Purple Prose: 8.0, Overwrought: 7.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 10.0, Unearned Transformations: 9.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 9.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 14.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 10.0, Overall Impression: 11.0
+ Biopunk: Polymerase Chain Reaction — Score: 47.5
Prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Here is a 1000 word chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world, focused on a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material: The ancient centrifuge whirred to life, its worn metal casing rattling as it spun the sample vials. Ava watched the machine intently, her brow furrowed in concentration. The survival of her entire settlement depended on the success of this experiment. After the collapse, the corporate biotech giants had engineered their crops with built-in obsolescence, ensuring their genetically-modified seeds would only last a single generation. It was a ruthless strategy to maximize profits before society crumbled. Now, Ava and her fellow biohackers were forced to scavenge through the ruins, piecing together salvaged lab equipment to splice together new, hardy strains of food crops from the rapidly degrading genetic material. She glanced over at the array of jury-rigged instruments arrayed on the workbench - an old laptop running custom DNA analysis software, a hotplate cobbled together from scavenged electronics, and a set of empty canisters from a defunct biotech company that now served as makeshift reagent containers. It was a far cry from the state-of-the-art labs she had trained in, but it would have to do. The centrifuge slowed to a stop, and Ava carefully removed the vials, inspecting the samples. The genetic material was already starting to degrade, the double helix unraveling with each passing day. She had to work quickly. Ava carefully pipetted the samples into the thermal cycler, her hands trembling slightly. This was the most critical step - using the polymerase chain reaction to amplify the viable DNA fragments before they were lost forever. She input the parameters into the laptop and pressed start, listening to the machine's rhythmic whirring. As the PCR process ran its course, Ava turned her attention to the other components of her experiment. She retrieved a tray of soil samples, examining them closely. The land around their settlement had been contaminated by industrial runoff, rendering much of the earth infertile. But Ava had been experimenting with various soil additives, trying to restore the nutrients and microbial diversity. She carefully mixed in a cocktail of salvaged probiotics, minerals, and organic matter, her fingers dancing across the makeshift lab equipment. This was as much an art as a science - balancing the delicate ecosystem of the soil to create the perfect growing medium. Ava was so absorbed in her work that she nearly jumped when the thermal cycler beeped, signaling the end of the PCR run. She hurried back to the laptop, scanning the results. The DNA had amplified successfully, but the degradation was still evident. She would need to run another round of PCR to get enough viable genetic material to work with. As the machine whirred to life again, Ava turned her attention to the final piece of the puzzle - the gene editing. She carefully pipetted the amplified DNA samples into a modified CRISPR system, one she had jury-rigged from scavenged parts. This was the riskiest part of the process, as the genetic modifications were largely untested. But they had no choice - without engineered crops, her settlement would starve. Ava input the target sequences, pausing to consider the potential consequences. The CRISPR system could theoretically be used to introduce beneficial traits like drought resistance or increased nutrient content. But it could also have unpredictable, even disastrous, effects. She steeled herself and pressed the execute button, watching as the modified DNA was injected into the soil samples. A sudden pounding at the door startled Ava, causing her to spill a vial of reagent. "Open up! This is the Black Market Enforcement Squad!" Her heart racing, Ava quickly grabbed a rag to soak up the spill. She couldn't afford any mistakes, not with the fate of her people hanging in the balance. Hurriedly, she opened the door to find two armed guards standing outside. "Ma'am, we've received a report of illegal genetic modification activities in this area," the lead guard said sternly. "Mind if we take a look around?" Ava's mind raced as she tried to formulate a response. "Uh, yes, of course. Come on in." She stepped aside, allowing the guards to enter the makeshift lab. The guards inspected the equipment, frowning at the jury-rigged nature of the setup. "This all looks pretty sketchy. You got a permit for this kind of operation?" Ava's mouth went dry. "Permit? No, I - we don't have one. But this is for the good of the community, I swear. We're just trying to grow food, to keep everyone alive." The guards exchanged a glance. "Well, that's a noble cause, I'll give you that. But the law's the law. We're gonna have to confiscate all this equipment and take you in for questioning." Ava's heart sank. "Please, you don't understand. Without this, my people will starve. You can't take it away!" The lead guard shook his head. "Sorry, ma'am. Can't make exceptions, even for a good cause." He motioned to his partner, who began gathering up the lab equipment. Ava watched in horror as her hard work was dismantled, the precious genetic samples in jeopardy. But then, she noticed something - the CRISPR system was still active, the modified DNA being injected into the soil samples. A glimmer of hope flickered within her. As the guards led her away, Ava allowed a small smile to cross her lips. Perhaps her reckless genetic modifications would prove more resilient than anyone expected. Maybe, just maybe, her settlement would find a way to survive after all.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This biopunk chapter attempts to create a post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering with built-in obsolescence has created a crisis. The protagonist, Ava, is a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to create viable food crops for her settlement. The piece does include many of the requested elements: jury-rigged lab equipment (the centrifuge, thermal cycler, modified CRISPR system), the concept of degrading genetic material, and a black market element in the form of the "Black Market Enforcement Squad." However, the execution has several significant weaknesses. The world-building lacks depth and specificity. While we get mentions of equipment, the descriptions are generic rather than vivid or technically interesting. The author tells us about "custom DNA analysis software" and "a hotplate cobbled together from scavenged electronics" without providing distinctive details that would make this world feel lived-in or unique. The physical toll and unexpected upsides of untested genetic modifications as medicine—a specific element requested in the prompt—are entirely absent. The narrative mentions that CRISPR could have "unpredictable, even disastrous, effects" but never explores what these might be or how they manifest. The black market contract, which was supposed to be central to the plot, is barely present. Instead, we get a generic confrontation with enforcement officers that feels rushed and lacks tension. The narrative doesn't explain what the "Black Market Enforcement Squad" is enforcing or why they care about Ava's activities. Character development is minimal. We learn almost nothing about Ava beyond her role as a biohacker. Her motivations are generic ("the survival of her entire settlement"), and we don't see her personality through distinctive actions, thoughts, or dialogue. The ending attempts a hopeful note but feels unearned and vague. The "small smile" Ava allows herself as she's being arrested doesn't connect to any specific plan or insight, just a nebulous hope that "her reckless genetic modifications would prove more resilient than anyone expected." The prose is functional but lacks distinctive style or rhythm. It relies heavily on telling rather than showing, with many sentences explaining concepts rather than immersing the reader in the experience. For example, "It was a ruthless strategy to maximize profits before society crumbled" is direct exposition rather than allowing the reader to discover this through the narrative. Overall, while the piece includes the basic elements requested, it fails to develop them into a compelling narrative with depth, originality, or emotional resonance.
